data.text: Does anybody have any experience with inflatable tents? I'm looking at the Alpkit aeronaut in particular. Any real world reviews are welcomed

I have one, have only used it once, it's definitely warmer than just a bivvy bag or bivvy bag and tarp. Packs down nice and small and has a bit of space for your bags. It's very low so you can't sit up in it, it's not well ventilated so there was quite a lot of condensation, it didn't rain but I worry water may have pooled at the foot end due to shape, if it had.
data.author: Barnz Starmer-Smith

data.text: did you leave a gap in the door section for ventilation, I've found with most tents that it needs to be not 100% closed to reduce condensation. I'm actually torn between the aeronaut and the soloist xl.

data.text: . I've bought a lot of Alpkit gear all great quality and price . I bought the Aeronaut 1 and it was well made and a fantastic price but .... The picture shows what happened when it rained . Because it has two poles at the foot end it collected water. If it had one pole it would form a ridge and water would run off . To me it's a bad design . Alpkit gave me a full refund . I'm generally super impressed with the company but not with this tent. I bought a Vango F10 helium 2 instead .

data.text: 1 vote for the Soloist here. Can get in it no probs with some bags. See on right of pic here. Much less claustrophobic than my pal's IOX Phoxx coffin next to it. The multiple pitch options are also handy and the full thing, including poles fits easily in my medium sized frame bag.

data.text: . It's good . Had up in rain and wind . All seems pretty sturdy. Not as compact as the aeronaut but it's a 2 man and you are only talking a few centimetres difference . Very easy to pitch ( all in one ) and packing is made very easy with the bag rather than the stuff sack. If packing away wet I'd separate the inner and but it in it's own bag before packing together to keep it dry . Ideal for one person . Love the two doors . Cook on either side if wind / rain changes direction . Also lets more air in on warm nights . No condensation issues yet ! If you keep poles separate you can really reduce pack size . So far 10/10 but haven't fully tested .
